body:
Hi moore,

Please check the following points:
1, What is the max _sentence_ length in **your dataset** (data.txt)? This is important because the `-maxsentlen` option should be set larger than the max sentence length to avoid memory overflow. You can also eliminate some outliers (i.e. with very long sentence).
2, What is the max dependency length in your dataset? The `-maxdeplen` should be set larger than the max dependency relation length (like, if your longest dependency relation is '3|123|4 5|9|7', then set `-maxdeplen 2`)

Please check them and tell me whether it will work.
Actually I used the dataset the author mentioned. So the default parameter should work.

Hi,

I tried the latest code on my dataset and it turned out to be ok. I guess there is something wrong with the official dataset? 
Unfortunately my vpn failed recently, so I cannot download the updated dataset and test on it. Would you mind posting several lines of `data.txt` here?
@svjan5 Thank you, and the code runs well on the 10 rows of data on my server.

Hi,

I tried to replace the data.txt with these 10 rows of data and ran the code. The same fault occurred. Could you tell me your specific running environment? I'm going to make sure everything is the same.

Hi @loginaway , can I ask you some detail question on we-chat? I think we-chat communication is more convenient for us.
My we-chat number is 'Moooooooooooore'. If possible, please sent me a message. I'm looking forward to your reply.

Hi moore,

Here are some information of my running environment.

Ubuntu 18.04 LTS
python 3.6.7
tensorflow              1.13.1      
tensorflow-gpu          1.8.0
I also met this fault, and tried every combinations of maxsentlen and maxdeplen. It doesn't worked.
Sorry for disturb you. Could you please check the code and help us to solve this problem? Thank you. If there is any improve, please let us know. Best wishes and sincerely thank you.

I'm sorry that we still haven't solved the problem. And although I am willing to help you to debug the code, I can't replicate the error even when the running environment is very similar (except for the gpus). 
For now the best solution seems to be switching to another device and test whether it will work.

Hi @IanLiYi1996,
The segmentation fault is only because of batch generation code which is in C++. If you are unable to resolve it because of machine architecture etc. You can try implementing the batch generation in python, it will be quite straightforward. Let me know if you need any help for that.
Thank you for your answer. I will modify and debug according to your method. If there is any progress, I will inform you.

Hi @IanLiYi1996,
You can also create a pull request once you have implemented it. It will be helpful for other users as well. 

Thanks

Hi @svjan5 @loginaway  ,

I have also met this error with the same dataset and same default setting. I found that the error begins from below line in the getBatch() method:
`wrds[cnt_wrds] = wid;
`
Current wrds value is: 0x7b9c45e0(Pi); wid value is: 24351; cnt_wrds value is: 0;
in the syngcn.py code, the constructed wrds are in the shape of (5120,) and everything seems correct but the subscription on the c++ side just keeps getting wrong (I guess it might be caused by non-aligned address). 

I am not familiar with C++ while I will try to find the reason, it would be great if you could also share some thoughts on this.

Thanks

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^UPDATE^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^:
I changed the obtaining address code to like:
```
edges_addr_t = ctypes.c_int*len(self.edges)
self.edges_addr = edges_addr_t(*self.edges)
wrds_addr_t  = ctypes.c_int*len(self.wrds)
self.wrds_addr = wrds_addr_t(*self.wrds)
...
...
elen_addr_t = ctypes.c_int*len(self.elen)
self.elen_addr  = elen_addr_t(*self.elen) 
```
Now the code can be run but the training loss is always `nan`:
![101571069581_ pic_hd](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19360686/66766393-e590d700-eea5-11e9-8872-7f94d35055ed.jpg)
(it seems that by doing so, the **value assignment on c++ side actually doesn't work, values are still zeros on python side**)
I guess it still have some problems with the assignment.....):

^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^UPDATE^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^:
I have successfully get it to run by **replacing**:
```
self.edges_addr = self.edges. __array_interface__['data'][0]
self.wrds_addr  = self.wrds.  __array_interface__['data'][0]
self.negs_addr  = self.negs.  __array_interface__['data'][0]
self.samp_addr  = self.samp.  __array_interface__['data'][0]
self.wlen_addr  = self.wlen.  __array_interface__['data'][0]
self.elen_addr  = self.elen.  __array_interface__['data'][0]
```
**to**:
```
self.edges_addr = self.edges.ctypes.data_as(ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_int))
self.wrds_addr = self.wrds.ctypes.data_as(ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_int))
self.negs_addr = self.negs.ctypes.data_as(ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_int))
self.samp_addr = self.samp.ctypes.data_as(ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_int))
self.wlen_addr = self.wlen.ctypes.data_as(ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_int))
self.elen_addr = self.elen.ctypes.data_as(ctypes.POINTER(ctypes.c_int))
```
Now the code is able to run and values assigned on c++ side are also modified to those arrays defined in python side, the training loss is no longer nan again.
